title: How to get my neighbor to take down his confederate flag - Quora
tags: Southern States Take Down Confederate Flag (June 2015)
Politics of the United States of America

response.answer_text: I appreciate the answers dealing with freedom of speech and that is a very important part of our freedoms. but let me point you in a different direction. Do you have a relationship with him? Then do over and mention the flag and ask him why he flies it. That will give you a great deal of insight. Is he some white power racist or does he just love the history and culture of the south or for some other reason. I doubt you will change his mind, but when others talk to you about it, you will be able to point out your differences, at the least.Not being from the south I loved the confederate flag on the top of the General Lee because it spoke of pride and independence, sometimes from corruption. I understood the south has a beautiful culture, traditions, and history, if you leave out the slavery issue or Jim Crow thinking.A few years ago I travelled to Stone Mountain that includes honoring civil war generals who fought for the south. Personally, there is much to honor them in their character and even in their brilliance. But I thought of others , like Martin Luther King who should also be on Stone Mountain. He was not perfect, none were, but we can honor many who did amazing things. A few months later I wrote the private foundation which runs the park and nicely suggested that they do just that. They never replied, but that was okay. I hope someone considered it. We should never forget our history, and see the many things we are trying to do better. I would not fly such a flag because it speaks of slavery to many, including many of my black friends. But put in context, it would be appropriate in a historic situation as a symbol of the south. After all, you can’t force someone to not put up the flag, but you might win him over so that he would not try to offend his black neighbors who might feel hurt by the history of slavery and the Jim Crow laws put in place which hurt his relatives.

I grew up on the Mississippi Gulf Coast. I wasn’t taught “The Civil War” in school. I was taught about “The War of Northern Aggression”. So, understand it’s entirely possible your neighbor was taught that way too. It’s nonsense about it being an inevitable war about tariffs with slavery being a small part of it as the South was already phasing it out. Heck, the big yearly field trip in my town’s 5th grade class was to go to Beauvoir, which is a very fancy name for the last home of Jefferson Davis. And that trip didn’t exactly try to teach you the South was the bad guys in all of that. Nor was my town anywhere near the only one to send their 5th graders there. Not by a long shot. The Rebels were glorified, and not at all disdained for their rebellion. And the fact that most of the great generals were in the South, so the only reason we lost was not having enough factories. It’s this bizarre alternate history that quite a few people buy into largely because it’s what they were taught. I can only offer you where I, as someone who went through that indoctrination, ended up. The Civil War was Capitalists vs the Aristocracy. Because the vast majority of the South’s population had absolutely nothing to do with the war. The rich conservatives in the South did not want to change. The more the country changed, the angrier they got. Slavery was just the straw that broke the camel’s back. They saw the writing on the wall and decided to try to stop progress. They massacred a great many people in an attempt to stop it. Gladly. The truth is, the vast majority of those who fought in the war never went to a Ball. They were never taught proper etiquette. They didn’t even listen to that kind of music. Their way of life was basically the same as dirt poor farmers everywhere. Sure the food changed and each region put their own twist on folk music, but by and large what people in Iowa did in their free time is the exact fucking thing poor people in Mississippi did. You know who was wrapped up in all that crap? Rich, white, conservative plantation owners. Who absolutely did own slaves. Which his ancestors almost assuredly did not own (a common counter argument to all of this) just like people whose ancestors came from freaking Vermont. The mythology behind the Confederates was built by the aristocracy of the South as a way to explain to all the poor people why they just suffered for 4 years. I mean, you don’t want to tell them the truth as they’d hang you. So you lie. You blame the North and tell them the war was inevitable. You tell them to remember how great it was before. Heck, you even ingrain what was once the ultimate symbol of wealth in the South into a staple for their homes. Iced Tea? Yeah, that originated from rich plantation owners showing off to their friends. Iced tea before refrigeration in the South meant you had money to burn. Now your waitress just assumes you want it with your meal. Go figure. You turn all the previous status symbols of wealth into things that most now just assume were always there for everyone. As if a dirt poor farmer gave a damn if his kids learned how to waltz or knew proper etiquette. And they were lucky to have a second pair of clothes that they could keep clean for church. I’m not seeing them sinking that much money into fancy suits and dresses. The flag is a lie told to generations of southerners as a method of control. Anytime change begins to affect the South they all rally around that flag. Honestly, not even the Germans got programmed as well as the South did. So you can try that angle… but I doubt it will work. I mean, when you have 4 or 5 generations of people who all think the same thing, it’s really hard to get them to change their mind. Blame Lincoln’s soft heart for all of that. He should have strung them up after a trial that would lay bare their treason and took control of the education system. Then maybe we wouldn’t be where we are today.

So, you'd like to force your neighbor to remove his Confederate flag? Let's consider exactly what this means on a larger picture, not just your dislike for the Confederate flag. First, if you can force your neighbor to remove his personal flag preference, then he could demand you take down whatever he finds offensive. Do you have one of those rainbow gay pride flags, a communist flag, a flag with Elsie the cow supporting drinking lots of milk? If he doesn't like whatever your flag of choice is then he can make you pull it down. Do you have a bumper sticker for Bernie or Trump or Hillary or Bozo the Clown for president? He may find that offensive as well, in fact I'm sure after you force your opinion on him then he will give you a taste of your own medicine. Second, is this the battle you real want to fight? Why do you want to battle over such a petty issue? Can't you imagine there are other, far more important things to invest your time and energy in, things like education for impoverished inner city kids, feeding homeless veterans, teaching kids to read, or just about any worthwhile cause or causes. Stop being such a petty person, let others just be themselves.

Suppose your neighbor flew the “Rainbow” flag? Suppose your neighbor flew a “Back the Blue” flag? Suppose your neighbor flew a flag of six shades of red and pink colors with a white bar in the center (the official Lesbian flag)? Suppose your neighbor flew the black POW-MIA flag? Suppose your neighbor flew (if you live in a southern state) the state’s historic Civil War battle flag? Suppose your neighbor flew the “Betsy Ross”flag? Suppose your neighbor flew the red and black “Antifa” flag? Or just suppose your neighbor flew the flag of his ethnic ancestory? Would any of these be okay according to your ideas of what is proper and right? I believe this falls under the first amendment protecting freedom of speech and expression. So, to answer your question, you don’t. If you ignore your neighbor’s flag things will probably go much better. Better yet, why don’t you ask him why he flies the flag. People like to do things simply to piss other people off …like maybe your neighbor; if you fall for it, he wins and you lose. You have no more right to ask your neighbor to remove his “Confederate” flag then I have in asking my neighbor to remove their “Rainbow” flag.

How do you get your neighbor to take down his Confederate Flag? The way you’d go about doing that is convincing him that there is no reason to have Southern Pride. You do know that that’s why most people who fly the rebel flag, do it, right? There is a small group of people who fly the Confederate flag because they are white supremacists. There are two reasons for that. One is that white supremacists are a very small percentage of our populace. The other is that the rest of the people who fly the Confederate flag won’t put up with people shaming the Confederate Flag like that. The vast majority of people who fly the Confederate Flag do it out of Southern Pride. Southern culture is a very rich culture in art, literature, music, fine food, beautiful architecture - I could go on and on, but you get the idea. You’re not going to convince him that southern culture is of no value. Perhaps if you learn about the amazing things southern culture has to offer, you won’t even want him take his flag down. Instead you’ll say to yourself: “How could I have been so oblivious to such an amazing culture and how could I have been so arrogant to think that only northern culture was of any value”?

Basically this is a fight you don't want to start. Leave it alone. Unless there is some sort of city ordinance that prohibits the flying of the Confederate flag, you have no legal standing, and his first amendment rights trump your right to be offended. Now if your neighbor is smart, he can really mess with you by flying an number of lesser known Confederate flags and you likely wouldn't know any better. You likely are thinking of the Army of Northern Virginia Southern cross battle flag. I doubt most people know what the stars and bars are. What about Polk's battle flag, the Missouri Southern Cross, the Kentucky Confederate flag, the South Carolina secession flag, the Florida secession flag, the Bonnie Blue flag, or Van Dorns battle flag. As a Civil War reenactor we did a mock battle with some kids at the Nebraska State Historical Society using Polk's battle flag in its Saint George's cross pattern instead of the Scottish based Saint Andrew's cross Southern Battle flag of the Army of Northern Virginia. I doubt anyone knew what we were up to. I don't care for the Confederate flag, either. My family fought for the Union and I consider the Southern cross battle flag a flag of treason. I respect the Southern right to be proud of their heritage as I am of mine. You need to leave this alone.

How do I get my neighbor to take down his confederate flag? Free speech is a bitch, ain’t it? And you either agree with free speech or you don’t. Of course when you live next to someone that speaks freely of things you do not agree with it can be an issue. If it bugs you that he is flying it, try asking him why. Maybe he is just proud of his southern heritage. Sometimes people surprise you with the reasons why they do what they do. Sometimes those surprises are pleasant ones. You may be surprised he is a nice person. I say that because I have relatives in the south that wear rebel flag t-shirts or such and are very good people. You may have a chance to understand this person on a different level. And yes, there are people that display the confederate flag ( or do other things) just because they are assholes. When you ask your neighbor maybe he has a good reason, or maybe he is an asshole. If so, you can move. If you do not want to move take a more drastic action such as a homeowners association or a petition. That stuff rarely works out well though. It is just a flag. It just sits there. Unless your neighbor is doing something more in your face and impossible to ignore…I would just let it go.

Buy a Juneteenth flag on Etsy that’s twice the size of his. Give it 24/7 lighting. Hold a big Juneteenth party on the weekend by June 19th. In fact buy several to give to friends and family. In case you’re wondering what Juneteenth is, it’s also known as Freedom Day or Emancipation Day. On June 19th, 1865 a Union general publicly declared in Texas that the Civil War was over and that all slaves were now free due to President Abraham Lincoln’s executive order in 1863, the Emancipation Proclamation. Modern Juneteenth celebrations include soul food, gospel music and negro spirituals, telling stories about the Underground Railroad and the Civil Rights Movement, replaying of Dr Kings I HAVE A DREAM speech, and RedVelvet cake to symbolize the blood shed during slavery, and the blood shed to end slavery. Make sure you give your neighbor an invitation to your Juneteenth party. Juneteenth flags also make lovely Christmas gifts; you could get him one to hang next to his confederate flag, y’know, so he can represent both sides of the story. If you’re wondering why I’m so keen on it, I make and sell Juneteenth flags on Etsy. Get your order in now before I get slammed!

Go ask him. If he refuses, remember it is his property and also remember that to some the Confederate flag is a symbol of southern pride and has nothing to do with racism. Also remember that despite what modern dogma says, you have no right not to be offended. Putting up with something which offends you is part of living in a free society. Someone else mentioned the flag on top of the General Lee on The Dukes of Hazzard and how to them it represented freedom and standing up to corruption. It reminded me of the TV show, My Big Redneck Vacation and how during one season they drove the family all across the country and exposed them to people who were very different than they were. They drove them around in a big Prevost motor coach that had a musical horn that played “Dixie” just like the General Lee. One episode had them having dinner with a Muslim family in Dearborn. The father of the Muslim family was a fan of The Dukes and flipped when he learned that the redneck family had a bus with a General Lee horn. He just had to go out and play with it. That was a guy who wasn’t walking around looking for things to be offended by.

My neighbors displayed the confederate flag in plain sight a few weeks after they moved into our neighborhood. They lived right across from me and my Caucasian husband. I grew up in New Jersey and Connecticut and was always told that it was a symbol of slavery. I read a lot of opinions on the subject and tried to understand it from every point of view. Most white Southerners said it was the “rebel flag” and it had little to do with slavery. My gay black boss was disappointed that I even considered looking it from a different perspective since I’m a brown-skinned gal with Indian ancestry. One day, I walked outside, stood in front of their house, and just stared at it. I don’t remember how long I stood in that spot. I wasn’t angry but I was a little spooked by it. I kept debating what to do. I wasn’t a confrontational person but I said a little prayer for peace in our neighborhood. I never took any action against them. Interestingly, the neighbors took it down a couple of days later. A few years later, my husband was trying to sell his aunt’s old car and guess who bought it? It turned out they were nice people. I never found out why they took the flag down. They were known as odd ducks and the police were called in more than once during their first year there. I’m assuming people complained again and they were asked to take it down by the police and/or the town.

Ask him something like “how long have you been a Democrat” or “which Democrat did you vote for”? He will be surprised and react as if you just called him a baby-killing, queer, child molester, then you tell him you assumed he was a Democrat because he is flying a Democrat flag. WHAT??? Yes, you tell him, I saw you flying the Democrat flag, so that’s how I knew you are a Democrat. WHAT??? Well of course he must know that General Lee and the rest of the Confederates were Democrats, right? You know, since Lincoln was a Republican and all. Ask him why he isn’t flying the Republican Civil War flag. What’s the Republican Civil War flag???  How do I get my neighbor to take down his confederate flag?

I had a neighbor who flew the Confederate Stars and Bars flag on a flag pole at his home. I realized that he would not entertain any conversation about his flag. After serious thought, I purchased this flag and flew it from my property:  Two weeks after I started flying my flag, he took his flag down - and then I took mine down. He hasn’t flown his Confederate Stars and Bars flag since and I have not flown mine. There is an old expression “Turn about is fair play”.

upvoters.user_id: Amir Hossein Talebi（アミルホセインタェビ）
Lani Kelly (百舌・ ケリー)

response.answer_text: Absent any covenants in a HOA agreement, you likely have no legal recourse to get him to take it down. Complaining directly to him is just what he wants (as people who do things like this are spoiling for an opportunity to either extol the virtues of their position, or start a fight about their rights). So ignore him. Not ignore the flag, but ignore the neighbor. Not in a way that is openly disdainful, but just treat him as someone for him you have no regard. Be distantly polite but ultimately indifferent to him. At some point, if he cares and if enough people act this way, he will realize that his childish display is the reason why he is being treated as if he and his opinions don’t matter. And either he will care, or he won’t.

If you don’t like it then don’t look at. I fly mINE on occasion. The Stars and Bars was NOTHING MORE THAN A BATTLE FLAG FOR THE CSA ARMY JUST AS THE STARS AND STRIPES WAS FOR THE USA ARMY. I’m a US MILITARY VETERAN. I’ll defend the Stars & Stripes until death if need be. I fly the Stars and Bars as a matter of Southern Pride. I was born in Atlanta Ga and have relatives that fought for the South. SO I SAY AGAIN IF YOU DONT LIKE IT DON’T LOOK AT IT. It’s really none of your business what he flies on his flag pole, however I’d most likely have something to say if it were a flag of an enemy of the USA.

Move to a country where there is no equivalent of the 1st amendment. The Confederate battle flag is an asshole move in of itself, flown by people who are either ignorant of the treason, betrayal and racism that it was intentionally designed to represent, or by people who understand the background but simply don’t care or have too much “FU” in them…But… This is America. You don’t get to tell your neighbor what flags he chooses in his expressions protected by the 1st amendment.

How do I get my neighbor to take down his confederate flag? In what way is he harming you? Maybe you should examine your own inability to accept anyone else’s beliefs, philosophies, or flag they care to fly. Is he actively out there pressuring you or other people to hate blacks, own slaves, or secede from the Union? No? Then STFU about it.

Why do you think you have the right to do that? How about growing up and not letting things get inside your head. Were you not taught to ignore things and go about life? Trust me it’s much better than dwelling on things and getting worked up over it.

You don’t. There is nothing illegal about showing of a confederate flag and you have no right to tell someone they can’t have a flag in front of their house. It’s not hurting anyone, it’s not hurting you, and if it bothers you ignore it. That’s the problem with the world today. Everybody has to take everyone else’s feelings into account. For example, I find Malcolm X to be insulting, he said horrible things about gays and Jews. I’m not demanding they tear down his statue though.

Semi related: a friend lived in Portadown in Northern Ireland. It is still quite a divided town with Protestant/Catholic riots every year or two, though her own road is a mixed community and everyone rubs along OK. Some "Loyalist" lads decided they were going to put up a Union Jack on one of the lamp posts in the street. This wasn't really welcomed by the residents, since they were all happy with the neutral stance of the street, but you'd have to be quite brave to challenge sectarian minded youths (from either side). Her (protestant) neighbour went to speak to them "Right lads, if you're going to put the flag up, you've got to do it right. You need to take it down at dusk and put it up again at dawn. You can't just abandon it all night as that's not showing proper respect". Having been "out-loyalisted" the flag came down and the street remained non-sectarian - exactly the result he'd wanted. Well played!

Look at it as history, not hate. Sure, there are some people who choose to use it, or look at it, as a racist symbol. The reality is it is a part of our American history. The other reality is that most people who don’t have southern roots or who have never lived in the south don’t understand that its meaning isn’t all about slavery. Even a cursory history of the south and its culture should be a bit enlightening. It’s not all about racism. I was born and raised in the worst part of Detroit you could possibly imagine and I can tell you, racism isn’t confined to any one region or practiced by any one race. If possible, talk to your neighbor. If he’s a jerk, then leave it alone. If he’s not, he may have an explanation for you. Who knows? Maybe his great-great grandfather was a West Point graduate who fought and died during the war.

Well answered as to people’s rights earlier. However anyone who flies what was most certainly never an actual Confederate flag of the Civil War is kind of an ass hat anyway. Why would you want to have a conflict with them? Better to share coffee, tea or drinks and get to know them. I’m betting some other issue is going on. Most of the people I know with similar radical views feel cut off from others and might benefit from a friend.

You can’t. You know you can’t. Call the cops, they’ll laugh at you. If you’re friends with your neighbor, you might be able to talk to them and suggest why you find that flag offensive. But, in the long run, it’s still his choice. It might irritate you, but you’re welcome not to look in his yard. That’s the thing about freedom of speech. Freedom of speech doesn’t mean freedom of consequences though. I mean, if he borrows your tools, you have the right to tell him no, you don’t want to do that anymore. You have the right not to invite him to a BBQ, even if you’ve invited him for years. But that’s about all you can do.

Don’t. Avert your eyes when you’re near it. Do you really want to engage with a guy rooting for the slavers? You know guys like him don’t really give a shit what you think anyway. It is so hard to predict he ain’t gonna take down that flag. But if you ask him, he might regard you as an abolitionist or something even worse — a goddamn Yankee.

You don’t. Your neighbor has the right to fly the Confederate flag on their own private property, so long as they don’t fly it higher than the US flag. Believe me, I’m no fan of the Confederate flag, but they still have the right to do it. People also have the right to fly France, Japan, or England’s flag- they just can’t fly it higher than the US flag. I have no clue why anyone would want to fly the Confederate flag still, and I do oppose it being flown on state property. This is more or less how I feel on the Confederate flag subject:  I’m a citizen of the United States. This is my flag, and this is my pledge, the original one:
The best way to get your neighbor to take down his Confederate flag is to raise a larger Confederate flag! Deo Vindice.

Something called the First Amendment applies. Contrary to Political Correctness, you have the right to say any stupid thing you want to say and as long as you are not interfering with other people’s rights, you can say it any way you want. Consider the flag as the person’s way of advertising his beliefs. Agree with those beliefs or disagree with them. That is your choice.
He’s obviously attempting to secede from the United States.  Muster the troops.  Alternatively, let your dog poop on his lawn.

I’m not a Southerner or a racist, but I’ve always liked the Stars and Bars, and I have no problem with anyone who flies it. Some people here are advising you to get into a dialogue with him so you can SHAME him into taking it down before it ‘offends’ his Black neighbors. Just who the frack do you think you are? You have NO right to tell him, or even ask him to remove it. If you don’t like him flying it, LOOK THE OTHER WAY. That’s what America is supposed to be about-freedom of choice, not .politically correct.

Believe it or not, that flag was called the rebel flag many moons ago. I knew a black truck driver way back when who flew the rebel flag. Question him about it and he'd say ' Well I own my own truck, book my own loads,go when and where I want-makes me a rebel. Used to be a rainbow had a pot of gold at the end. Now the 'okay' thumb and finger sign is supposedly white power, though that started in a satirical web site. But that was enough for the MSM to make it so, and now the 'bagged you' game, which was a faze in the Marines in the mid-70's,means white power no matter what the intention. Heck, used to be a faggot was a bundle of sticks. And nigerdly ment stingy.

You can't. It's their property, no matter how much you disagree with what it stands for (for the record, so do I). You can talk to your neighbor and ask, but unless you live in an HOA neighborhood and this violates one of your covenants, you cannot compel it's removal. We had a situation like this happen in my community recently. A white woman moved into a predominantly black neighborhood and flew the Confederate flag from her front porch. They protested, but she refused to budge. So, one of her neighbors erected a fence around his property to obscure his view of her property.

Your rights end at your property line. Are you so triggered by the sight of something that you think means something but may mean something else entirely to the person displaying it? Get over it, YOU are the only one that can offend yourself. Its YOUR attitude that creates a state of offence in your own mind. Next time buy a house that is part of a home owners association.

Be civil and ask him to remove it first then burn It if he is being an butthole about it. Nothing wrong with burning a confederate flag. You might get in a little trouble for destroying his property. If it mysteriously ends up on your property then somehow bursts into flames you should be in the clear.

Just rip it down when no one's looking. Or set it on fire. I did it while he watched. Uhuh mothafcka….I know what that flag means. Racist cracker!!! He threw hands and got beat down on my doorstep. That was the end of that. Enough is enough. I ain't MLK JR!! (RIP)

In order to answer your question, we need some additional information. Where do you reside? Which flag, once flown by the CSA, is your neighbor flying? The Bonnie Blue Flag? The First National Flag (a.k.a. “The Stars and Bars”)? The Second National Flag (a.k.a. “The Stainless Banner”)? The Third National Flag? The Army of Northern Virginia Battle Flag? The Army of Tennessee Battle Flag? The Hardee-pattern Battle Flag? The Polk-pattern Battle Flag? The Van Dorn-pattern Battle Flag? The Richard Taylor-pattern Battle Flag? Any of the scores of other flags flown by the CSA? This is important. Unless you know the differences between these flags, in their historical context - and can identify them, on sight - you really lack credibility in opining about such things.

You can’t force him, and you can’t argue with him. IF he’s an otherwise decent human being, you can tell him quietly, “Joe, I know you’re not a bigot or a Klansman, but when you fly that flag, you’re essentially telling the world you are. Maybe you think you’re just honoring your ancestors, but every non white family in this neighborhood is going to think you’re a jerk who’s flipping them the middle finger. Think about it. Is that really what you want!”

Talk to them. Don’t start with his flag. Just go over and make friends. After you have established a friendship then ask him about it. Keep your opinions to your self. He may say some thing that might make you see it from his view. If after that it still offends you then talk to him in a calm manor. He will be much more likely to listen and see value in your opinion if you have shown him you value his opinion. This all assumes you want to take the high road. If you are okay with living next to a person who hates you and wants to make your life harder then by all means try to force the issue.

Just about the same way I can stop people from asking stupid fucking questions. I can't and you can't so you are going to have to put your self imposed morals and values on a shelf. A better idea would be to confront them and take it down for them…

If you’re in an association you may be able to. Otherwise there aren’t many options, if you ever did become friendly with him you could eventually ask. If you’re a person of color you might tell him you’re offended. If you’re a Caucasian you can’t really say that without virtue signaling. That’s all I can think of.

You don't. Your neighbour has every right to fly that flag if he so chooses. You on the other hand do not have any right not to be offended by something your neighbour does. Time to suck it up, put on your big person pants and deal with it. What would possibly give you the idea that you have the right to impose your views upon anybody else?

Well, you could ask him politely. He might take it down, he might tell you to stuff it. It’s his right to fly whatever flag he wants, whether you like it or not. For the moment, at least, we still have some level of freedom of speech here in the US, but the left is slowly working to erode it.

Yes, as others have said, this is their “right”. Chances are if you ask them, “Why?” as some suggest, the answer will not be at all appeasing. In this day and age, regardless of what the stated reason, flying this flag outside is more about making a “statement” than any overwhelming desire to honor their ancestors. Most of us do this at their gravesites. People who fly it obviously know that it offends many people and simply don’t care. That is their right. My answer to this would be to buy a Civil War regulation 34 star Union Cav. gideon, a replica of the one carried at Appomattox, and fly it. Chances are fairly good that your neighbor won’t know what it is but you will know that it symbolizes the last major battle of the Civil War where Lee surrendered to Grant effectively ending the Civil War in the Union’s favor. That is your right. Fair exchange.
You can't. Welcome to life--people do things that you don't like. I recommend ignoring that the flag exists and going about your daily life because that's what adults do.

AS a southerner, I am disgusted by that flag, not as much because it was used in the Civil War but what it has represented since then. I am horrified that certain states added it to their flags right after the Brown v Board of Education decision 65 years ago. It does NOT stand for “Southern Heritage” as some mistakenly claim. Coca Cola does that. Southern Fried Chicken with mashed potatoes and turnip greens and hushpuppies with pecan pie and sweet iced tea does that. Saying, “Good Morning or Afternoon” to people whom you pass on the street is Southern Heritage. Segregation and Jim Crowe and black people needing to pass a literacy test to vote and restaurants being permitted to refuse service to people because of skin color which that flag does represent are NOT THINGS TO BE PROUD OF in the United States of America. BUT, because I believe in freedom of speech, I actually encourage those who believe in the things that the CSA battle flag represents to fly it and even to wear it proudly. Then we can know easily whom to stay the HELL away from.

This is part of living in a country that guarantees the right to free speech. We have to endure view points that run contrary to our own. This is what is great about our country we get to say whatever stupid thing we want. There are plenty of stupid people out there as well. Respecting another persons right to free speech does not mean you agree with them. It has nothing to do with what their saying. This is what a civilized and mature people do. Your neighbor is probably an asshole, but thats his problem, not yours.

You don’t. In fact, if you’re wise, you will leave the subject alone. I’m sorry, but the flag he flies is his business. And if you attempt to tell him otherwise, he may put two out there just to show you he can—I would. If you go and tear it down, you are subject to criminal prosecution. I don’t think you can win this fight, so just mind your own affairs and leave it alone.

Freedom is messy and even scary sometimes.  Rather like the rattle of a rattlesnake it warms me that there is danger there.  Rather like the distinctive coloration of a wasp is also a warning.  Let them fly that stupid loser flag. Let them warn the world that this is a dangerous person. Then just go on with your life, but keep an eye on them.
